user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_SocketOpen:
```c
int32 OS_SocketOpen(osal_id_t *sock_id, OS_SocketDomain_t Domain, OS_SocketType_t Type)
{
    OS_object_token_t            token;
    OS_stream_internal_record_t *stream;
    int32                        return_code;

    /* Check for NULL pointers */
    OS_CHECK_POINTER(sock_id);

    /* Note - the common ObjectIdAllocate routine will lock the object type and leave it locked. */
    return_code = OS_ObjectIdAllocateNew(LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE, NULL, &token);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        stream = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_stream_table, token);

        /* Save all the data to our own internal table */
        memset(stream, 0, sizeof(OS_stream_internal_record_t));
        stream->socket_domain = Domain;
        stream->socket_type   = Type;

        /* Now call the OS-specific implementation.  This reads info from the table. */
        return_code = OS_SocketOpen_Impl(&token);

        /* Check result, finalize record, and unlock global table. */
        return_code = OS_ObjectIdFinalizeNew(return_code, &token, sock_id);
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
return_code = OS_ObjectIdAllocateNew(LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE, NULL, &token);
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 8.13 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation: the &token argument is intended to be modified by OS_ObjectIdAllocateNew (it returns the allocated token), so the pointer must not be to a const-qualified type. The NULL second argument is compatible with any pointer type and does not imply a missing const qualification. A violation would occur only if OS_ObjectIdAllocateNew actually does not modify the pointee of one of its pointer parameters but its parameter type is non-const (for example if its prototype were int OS_ObjectIdAllocateNew(int, void *p, OS_object_token_t *t) yet the function only reads from p — then p should be declared const void *), but that is not evident from this call site.
